title: Support list settings for extensions
body:
If I understand https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/contribution-points#contributes.configuration correctly, then it is currently impossible for an extension to add a multi-option list-like setting.

For example: I have an extension that supports multiple accounts which I want to configure via vscode's settings. Each account would have an entry with `username`, `email`, etc. I can do this for **one** account, but not for multiple (without resorting to dirty hacks).

Could this be added to the configuration contribution point to support some form of arrays of classes/containers?

title: Electron 7+: Use Touch Bar accessibilityLabels for VoiceOver
body:
Hey,
the buttons in VSCode are not labeled for VoiceOver, because this buttons use only icons. I understand, that icons are better as text labels. I searched in the code of electron, whether we can easily use a accessibilityLabel, that VoiceOver can read out. This has the advantage that the design of the Touch Bar-elements haven't to change, only a attribute have to add.
I found out, that electron don't offer a accessibilityLabel for Touch Bar-controls, so I opened a issue.
[here](https://github.com/electron/electron/pull/20454) is the issue fixed, very fast. :-)
So, electron offers now an AccessibilityLabel for Touchbar-controls.
Hopefully this feature can be merged in VSCode.
When this is not possible, in the next time, a work-around can be, to use text labels, if the accessibility mode is turned on.
What do you think?

best regards,
Christopher

title: Pausing the current thread provides the wrong thread ID
body: Even if the DA sends an exit event for a thread ID, VSCode will still use it in the pause request.

title: Support retainContextWhenHidden in Custom Editors
body:
1. Open a tab from an extension using the Custom Editor API (eg. image preview)
2. Switch to another tab
3. Switch back to the custom editor.

Observe that the webview needs to start up again from a blank screen and loses all state.

It would be nice if it were possible to enable retainContextWhenHidden for Custom Editor webview panels.
https://code.visualstudio.com/api/extension-guides/webview#retaincontextwhenhidden

(As mentioned in this [comment](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/77131#issuecomment-536868170) from the Custom Editors issue)

title: Write a better smoke test for the terminal
Replacing inline adds cases to the replace dialog history
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.38.1
- OS Version: Windows x64 10.0.17763

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Highlight a word in the editor
2. Use command "Add selection to next find match"
3. type to replace word
4. Open the find and replace dialog
5. In the find section the word that was just highlighted is current and any previous ones are bumped.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

Bug: Either the text that replaced the highlighted words should be in the replace field of the find and replace dialog or (preferably) this action has no effect on the find and replace or find dialog

title: typescript.tsdk setting not applied as an implicit workspace /.vscode/settings.json setting
body:
This happens in both VS Code v1.38.1 and Insiders v1.39.0

VSCode Version: v1.38.1 and v1.39.0
OS Version: macOS 10.14.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add the following to your /.vscode/settings.json
```
{
    "typescript.tsdk": null
}
```
2. Notice that the `typescript.tsdk` setting shows the message "This setting cannot be applied now. It will be applied when you open this folder directly.", meaning that this setting is not valid as an [implicit workspace setting](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/77718#issuecomment-539662926).

This is half bug report, half feature request: the setting 's description states:
```
Specifies the folder path to the tsserver and lib*.d.ts files under a TypeScript
install to use for IntelliSense, for example: ./node_modules/typescript/lib.

When specified as a user setting, the TypeScript version from typescript.tsdk
automatically replaces the built-in TypeScript version.

When specified as a workspace setting, typescript.tsdk allows you to switch to use
that workspace version of TypeScript for IntelliSense with the TypeScript: Select
TypeScript version command.

See the TypeScript documentation for more detail about managing TypeScript versions.
```

Even though the description doesn't differentiate between [implicit and explicit workspaces](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/77718#issuecomment-539662926), it would be expected that this setting would work inside the `/.vscode/settings.json` file. If that expectation is correct, this is a bug report. If it doesn't yet work inside an implicit workspace, it's a feature request - and in that case, I'll create a bug report asking to clarify the setting's description in the meanwhile.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled? Yes

title: Ambiguous/confusing implicit workspace settings feedback
body:
This happens in both VS Code v1.38.1 and Insiders v1.39.0

- VSCode Version: v1.38.1 and v1.39.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.14.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Copy all your default settings to any repository's /.vscode/settings.json
2. Notice that a few settings show the message "This setting cannot be applied now. It will be applied when you open this folder directly."

This message implies that these settings cannot be applied _now_, but may _sometime in the future_ and that opening the .vscode folder directly would apply them, which makes no sense.

I suggest changing the message to: "This setting is not applicable in an implicit workspace's .vscode folder's settings. It is only applicable in your user settings.json file or in an explicit workspace .code-workspace file."

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled? Yes

title: Provide fs.openDir() API over fs.readDir() to scale better for large directory structures
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
NodeJS > 12.11.1 will have async readdir support Landed in cbd8d71 ( https://github.com/nodejs/node/commit/cbd8d715b2286e5726e6988921f5c870cbf74127 ) as fs{Promises}.opendir(), which returns an fs.Dir, which exposes an async iterator.

This will allow us to open big directorys without issues. 

first step would be identify all places that do the old readdir calls and refactor them to use iterators till we switch to node > 12.11.1 when we then have switched we can simply replace the function name and are ready.

### Current State
- Promoting change in existing module dependencys from 3th
- Explore and create other Tickets here to use the new functionality,

title: Font rendering issues on macOS Catalina
body:
Issue Type: Bug After upgrading to macOS Catalina, the system font used in Visual Studio Code looks very narrow - and different from other apps in macOS Catalina. It seems that instead of using **SF Pro Text**, Visual Studio Code uses **.SF NS** on macOS Catalina. This is probably due to a bug in Chromium which I have reported here: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1012247 VS Code version: Code 1.38.1 (b37e54c98e1a74ba89e03073e5a3761284e3ffb0, 2019-09-11T13:31:32.854Z) OS version: Darwin x64 19.0.0

title: `workbench.action.terminal.rename` should accept name as an argument

milestone.title: Backlog

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently, `workbench.action.terminal.rename` command doesn't accept any argument. I wanted to make macros that renames current terminal after performing some other actions.

At the moment, it requires user prompt interaction.

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/f0faef0dd7abdb4e823d32ef21c557123427e0b3/src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminal/browser/terminalActions.ts#L1053-L1066

title: when debugging extension, value 'Infinity' in Debug Console showed as `null`

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

I made a simple vscode extension [ascii-tree-generator](https://github.com/aprilandjan/ascii-tree-generator) months ago. Recently I found that, when press <kbd>F5</kbd> and enter extention debugging, and use `console.log` to output a variable which is actually `Infinity`, the `Debug Console` showed it as `null` instead of `Infinity`. This is confusing and seems buggy.

I tried a newly created extension project from `yo code` template, it is still the same.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7011247/66399539-62d5cb00-ea12-11e9-8c5a-85ba5b81e01c.png)


in `Debug Console`:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7011247/66399585-7aad4f00-ea12-11e9-9eb2-ccee79a13724.png)


<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.38.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.14.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. create a template extension project follow this [official guide](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/get-started/your-first-extension)
2. add test script in `activate` method:

```typescript
console.log('Congratulations, your extension "test-ext" is now active!');
const a: number = Infinity;
console.log(a, null, a === null);
```

3. press <kbd>F5</kbd> to enter extension debugging;
4. run this extension command to activate the extension;
5. check the `Debug Console` in source project window. It showed as:

```bash
Congratulations, your extension "test-ext" is now active!
null null false
```

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Lost a whole day of work
body:
Today I started Visual Studio Code and it opened by default the project I was working on yesterday. The project is a Vuejs web application, opened as a **local folder**, and **not included into any version control**. I noticed that as I clicked, two instances of VSCode where opened, that seemed equal to me, so I closed the one opened last.
When running the aplication I saw multiple errors that shouldn't be there, and when I checked the files all the changes for the last 24 hours where reverted.
No message was shown, no confirmation dialogs and no questions for actions. It simply ate the work. Now:

- Is this supposed to be normal? If so, I would drop that environment at lightspeed (perhaps I will do anyways)
- How I can get back my work? Yesterday it all was saved right, without issues, this should be anywhere.
- How can I stop it doing this shit? For being able to revert It should have been saving incremental files without permission. How can this be stopped?
- Should I also scan all the solution for plugins and node components silently deleted, and configurations altered, even when internal?

My system runs Kubuntu 19.04 and VSCode v1.38.1

> Version: 1.38.1
> Commit: b37e54c98e1a74ba89e03073e5a3761284e3ffb0
> Date: 2019-09-11T13:30:08.229Z
> Electron: 4.2.10
> Chrome: 69.0.3497.128
> Node.js: 10.11.0
> V8: 6.9.427.31-electron.0

title: Allow users to clear confirmedUriHandlerExtensionIds
body:

title: Drag-and-drop indented blocks of code

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Make it possible to move blocks of code by indentation levels, like so:
https://wiki.mindey.com/shared/shots/0cbe7349349c0b14efabbbcd7-vscode-feature-request--moving-indented-blocks-with-mouse-to-other-levels-of-indentation.mp4

Related idea: https://www.halfbakery.com/idea/Software_20Development_20IDE_20as_20Lists_20Editor

title: Insiders fails to set default settings value for an array of strings after an extension is first installed
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.39.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install the C/C++ extension.

Bug: Errors occur in the Toggle Developer Console window due to the fact that C_Cpp.commentContinationPatterns default value of [ "/**" ] isn't being used. The bug doesn't repro in the non-Insiders VS Code or after reloading the window. We can workaround this bug via checking for the undefined value and manually setting the default (but the root issue could cause other extensions to fail).

Our package.json is at 
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-cpptools/blob/release/Extension/package.json

Activating extension 'ms-vscode.cpptools' failed: Cannot read property 'forEach' of undefined.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

title: fails to open 4GB text files
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.38.1
- OS Version: Lastest MacOS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a 4+GB system log file
2. VS Code will take for ever to open

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

I frequently work with large system dump files glog or vim handle these files very easily
Difficult to open/search using VSCode
